title: 1956 Porsche 356A European Cabriolet
description: This 1956 Porsche 356A is one of just a handful of Reutter-built cabriolets originally badged with “European” script on the front fender. The car was stored from 1980 until 2012, when it underwent a two-year refurbishment by Meister Restorations of New Hampshire that included a repaint, a reupholstered interior, and rebuilds of the 1.6-liter flat-four and four-speed manual transaxle. It is finished in Aquamarine Blue Metallic over red leather, and equipment includes a blue soft top, 15" ventilated steel wheels, body-color bumpers, a Blaupunkt radio, and bucket seats. This 356A European cabriolet was acquired by the selling dealer in 2025 and is now offered in North Salem, New York with a copy of the Kardex, a Porsche Certificate of Authenticity, handwritten notes and mileage logs, refurbishment records, a tool kit, manufacturer's literature, and New Hampshire registration.
author: bringatrailer
excerpt: Bid for the chance to own a 1956 Porsche 356A European Cabriolet at auction with Bring a Trailer, the home of the best vintage and classic cars online. Lot #194,846.
text: This 1956 Porsche 356A is one of just a handful of Reutter-built cabriolets originally badged with “European” script on the front fender. The car was stored from 1980 until 2012, when it underwent a two-year refurbishment by Meister Restorations of New Hampshire that included a repaint, a reupholstered interior, and rebuilds of the 1.6-liter flat-four and four-speed manual transaxle. It is finished in Aquamarine Blue Metallic over red leather, and equipment includes a blue soft top, 15″ ventilated steel wheels, body-color bumpers, a Blaupunkt radio, and bucket seats. This 356A European cabriolet was acquired by the selling dealer in 2025 and is now offered in North Salem, New York with a copy of the Kardex, a Porsche Certificate of Authenticity, handwritten notes and mileage logs, refurbishment records, a tool kit, manufacturer’s literature, and New Hampshire registration. The “European” designation of the US-market 356A was adopted following a lawsuit from Ford due to Porsche’s usage of the “Continental” name. This example is finished in Aquamarine Blue Metallic (5607) and was repainted during the aforementioned refurbishment following the completion of repairs, including in the floors, left door opening, fenders, left rocker, jack point, battery box, nose, and engine bay. Gold “European” badging is present on the front fenders, and the blue soft top is shown in the raised position in the gallery. The 15″ ventilated steel wheels wear chrome hubcaps and are mounted with 165R15 Cooker Classic whitewall tires. The car was factory equipped with drum brakes at each corner. The suspension and brakes were overhauled during the refurbishment. The bucket seats were upholstered in red leather, beige squareweave carpets were installed, and the Blaupunkt radio was repaired during the refurbishment. A set of Coco floor mats accompanies the vehicle. The two-spoke steering wheel frames VDO instrumentation consisting of a central 6k-rpm tachometer, a 120-mph speedometer, and a combination gauge monitoring oil temperature and fuel level. The five-digit odometer shows 9k miles, and total mileage is unknown. The 1.6-liter flat-four was rebuilt during the refurbishment and was fitted with Wossner forged 82.5mm pistons. Power is routed to the rear wheels through a four-speed manual transaxle. Manufacturer’s literature is included in the sale. The Porsche Certificate of Authenticity shows “European” designation, though no other information is available.  A copy of the Kardex is viewable in the gallery. The vehicle is being sold on its New Hampshire registration, which serves as an ownership document in New York. You are not connected to real-time updates. Attempting to connect. html:
This 1956 Porsche 356A is one of just a handful of Reutter-built cabriolets originally badged with “European” script on the front fender. The car was stored from 1980 until 2012, when it underwent a two-year refurbishment by Meister Restorations of New Hampshire that included a repaint, a reupholstered interior, and rebuilds of the 1.6-liter flat-four and four-speed manual transaxle. It is finished in Aquamarine Blue Metallic over red leather, and equipment includes a blue soft top, 15″ ventilated steel wheels, body-color bumpers, a Blaupunkt radio, and bucket seats. This 356A European cabriolet was acquired by the selling dealer in 2025 and is now offered in North Salem, New York with a copy of the Kardex, a Porsche Certificate of Authenticity, handwritten notes and mileage logs, refurbishment records, a tool kit, manufacturer’s literature, and New Hampshire registration.

The “European” designation of the US-market 356A was adopted following a lawsuit from Ford due to Porsche’s usage of the “Continental” name. This example is finished in Aquamarine Blue Metallic (5607) and was repainted during the aforementioned refurbishment following the completion of repairs, including in the floors, left door opening, fenders, left rocker, jack point, battery box, nose, and engine bay. Gold “European” badging is present on the front fenders, and the blue soft top is shown in the raised position in the gallery.

The 15″ ventilated steel wheels wear chrome hubcaps and are mounted with 165R15 Cooker Classic whitewall tires. The car was factory equipped with drum brakes at each corner. The suspension and brakes were overhauled during the refurbishment.

The bucket seats were upholstered in red leather, beige squareweave carpets were installed, and the Blaupunkt radio was repaired during the refurbishment. A set of Coco floor mats accompanies the vehicle.

The two-spoke steering wheel frames VDO instrumentation consisting of a central 6k-rpm tachometer, a 120-mph speedometer, and a combination gauge monitoring oil temperature and fuel level. The five-digit odometer shows 9k miles, and total mileage is unknown.

The 1.6-liter flat-four was rebuilt during the refurbishment and was fitted with Wossner forged 82.5mm pistons.

Power is routed to the rear wheels through a four-speed manual transaxle.

Manufacturer’s literature is included in the sale.

The Porsche Certificate of Authenticity shows “European” designation, though no other information is available.  A copy of the Kardex is viewable in the gallery.

The vehicle is being sold on its New Hampshire registration, which serves as an ownership document in New York.
